events.name: Angular JS Bootcamp
events.description:
AngularJS (also written as Angular.js) is a JavaScript-based open-source front-end web application framework mainly maintained by Google and by a community of individuals and corporations to address many of the challenges encountered in developing single-page applications.

It aims to simplify both the development and the testing of such applications by providing a framework for client-side model–view–controller (MVC) and model–view–viewmodel (MVVM) architectures, along with components commonly used in rich Internet applications. (This flexibility has led to the acronym MVW, which stands for "model-view-whatever" and may also encompass model–view–presenter and model–view–adapter.)

events.name: React JS Masterclass
events.description:
React (also known as React.js or ReactJS) is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It is maintained by Facebook and a community of individual developers and companies.

React can be used as a base in the development of single-page or mobile applications. Complex React applications usually require the use of additional libraries for state management, routing, and interaction with an API.

events.name: Crash course in MongoDB
events.description:
MongoDB is a cross-platform document-oriented database program. It is issued under the Server Side Public License (SSPL) version 1, which was submitted for certification to the Open Source Initiative but later withdrawn in lieu of SSPL version 2. Classified as a NoSQL database program, MongoDB uses JSON-like documents with schemata. MongoDB is developed by MongoDB Inc.

MongoDB supports field, range query, and regular expression searches. Queries can return specific fields of documents and also include user-defined JavaScript functions. Queries can also be configured to return a random sample of results of a given size.

events.name: Mastering Node JS and Express
events.description:
Node.js is an open-source, cross-platform JavaScript run-time environment that executes JavaScript code outside of a browser. Typically, JavaScript is used primarily for client-side scripting, in which scripts written in JavaScript are embedded in a webpage's HTML and run client-side by a JavaScript engine in the user's web browser. Node.js lets developers use JavaScript to write command line tools and for server-side scripting - running scripts server-side to produce dynamic web page content before the page is sent to the user's web browser. Consequently, Node.js represents a "JavaScript everywhere" paradigm, unifying web application development around a single programming language, rather than different languages for server side and client side scripts.

The Node.js distributed development project, governed by the Node.js Foundation, is facilitated by the Linux Foundation's Collaborative Projects program.

sessions.name: Introduction to Angular JS
sessions.speaker: John Doe
sessions.abstract: In this session you will learn about the basics of Angular JS

sessions.name: Scopes in Angular JS
sessions.speaker: John Doe
sessions.abstract: This session will take a closer look at scopes.  Learn what they do, how they do it, and how to get them to do it for you.

sessions.name: Controllers
sessions.speaker: Jane Doe
sessions.abstract: Controllers are the beginning of everything Angular does. They contain business logic used by your views.

sessions.name: Services
sessions.speaker: Jane Doe
sessions.abstract: Services implement the business logic that is used across an application. A common use case is to make backend calls.

sessions.name: Directives
sessions.speaker: Rob Smith
sessions.abstract: Directives are ways to teach HTML new tricks. Directives are either custom HTML elements or attributes. They encapsulate markup and functionality, and help create reusable widgets that can be used in the app at many places.

sessions.name: Introduction to React JS
sessions.speaker: Paul Smith
sessions.abstract: In this session you will learn about the basics of React JS

sessions.name: JSX
sessions.speaker: Paul Smith
sessions.abstract: Learn how to use JSX to create view and bind data to it

sessions.name: Props and children
sessions.speaker: Jane Doe
sessions.abstract: Use props and children to pass data

sessions.name: Components
sessions.speaker: Jane Doe
sessions.abstract: Create custom stateful and stateless components. Compose components to create your application.

sessions.name: State and application lifecycle
sessions.speaker: Rob Smith
sessions.abstract: Store application data in state and make your application respond to events

sessions.name: React router
sessions.speaker: Rob Smith
sessions.abstract: Add React router to build an SPA

sessions.name: State and application lifecycle
sessions.speaker: Rob Smith
sessions.abstract: Redux provides an architecture for state manipulation in your app. Add Redux to store the state of your app, and make your app respond to changes in state.

sessions.name: Introduction to NoSQL databases
sessions.speaker: Ramcharan Gupta
sessions.abstract: What NoSQL is and how it is different from RDBMSes

sessions.name: Understanding MongoDB
sessions.speaker: Ramcharan Gupta
sessions.abstract: MongoDB and its features shall be briefly introduced

sessions.name: Queries in MongoDB
sessions.speaker: John Doe
sessions.abstract: CRUD operations in MongoDB

sessions.name: Designing Schemas for MongoDB
sessions.speaker: Jane Doe
sessions.abstract: Schema design for MongoDB is quite different from that of traditional databases. Learn the art of designing Mongo DB database schemas for the application at hand.

sessions.name: Aggregation pipeline
sessions.speaker: Rob Smith
sessions.abstract: Learn how to use the aggregation pipelines to generate reports

sessions.name: Mobx in Action
sessions.speaker: Paul Smith
sessions.abstract: In this session you will learn about the basics of usin Mobx

sessions.abstract: Hello

sessions.abstract: Advanced advanced
